thread.section_title: New York High School Sports Coverage, Photos, HS Hoops, Recaps - NY Daily News
thread.title: 20 to love!

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: 20 to love!
text:
Shinann Featherston The Mayor's Cup girls singles tennis champ goes to a Catholic school in Queens. The boys champ played at an Ivy Prep League school in Manhattan. The girls doubles champs? They played their tennis in Brooklyn in the PSAL.
Leagues don't matter in tennis, and this season's Mayor's Cup champions illustrated that point. Bring your best forehand and your most massive serve, and you always have a chance to prevail.
Observers of many other sports will debate the pros and cons of the Big Apple's numerous interscholastic sports leagues, feeding endless arguments about which one boasts the superior level of competition. The existence of the Mayor's Cup competitions, however, gives tennis players the opportunity to take on the complete city circuit, settling questions about the top teams and individuals right there on the court.
That's why this year's Tennis All-Star team - selected by the New York Junior Tennis League and the Mayor's Cup All-Scholastic Tennis Championship Committee - showcases so much diversity. Among the squad's 20 players are 12 PSAL talents, two CHSAA standouts and six private school prospects.
Here's a look at this season's selections:
Girls Varsity
Jillian Santos Shinann Featherston, St. Francis Prep
In addition to playing first singles for the Terriers, Featherston closed her junior year with a third consecutive Mayor's Cup singles title. Featherston, who is ranked No. 15 in the nation in girls' 18-and-under and is sponsored by Wilson, also led the Terriers to their eighth consecutive Mayor's Cup team win.
Jillian Santos, Cardozo
Senior ended her scholastic career by running to the Mayor's Cup final before falling to Featherston. The Judges captain also led Cardozo to a third straight PSAL semifinal appearance and earned the Billie Jean King Award for excellence in athletics and academics.
Laken King and Carlissa King, Midwood
Laken King and Carlissa King Twins led Midwood to the PSAL team title, then romped to the Mayor's Cup doubles crown. Laken won the Brian Watkins Award for leadership and the PSAL Heisman-Wingate Award, given yearly to the PSAL's top senior in each sport. The Kings will play at Amherst University this fall.
Valeriya Tatisheva, The Dwight School
Powerful freshman earned fifth seed in Mayor's Cup, then advanced to the semifinals before falling to top seed Featherston. The 124th-ranked girls 14-and-under player in the nation, Tatisheva is one of the city's future stars.
Katarina Kovacevic, The Dwight School
A strong baseliner with a massive serve, Kovacevic made the Mayor's Cup semifinals before falling to second-seeded Santos in three sets.
Stacey Lopez Akilah James, Banneker
Ended freshman year as first singles player. Played in 2007 PSAL girls individual tourney and advanced to Mayor's Cup quarterfinals.
Veronica Li, Stuyvesant
No. 46 in USTA Eastern girls 16-and-under. Will play Eastern sectionals in girls 18-and-under division next fall.
Stacey Lopez, Beacon School
Curtis Roby Quarterfinalist at Mayor's Cup. Played first doubles for Beacon and first singles for NYJTL in national junior competition in California last fall.
Nadejda Demidenko, Poly Prep
Blue Devils senior ranked No. 16 in USTA Eastern girls 18-and-under play. Holds 22-12 record in Eastern tournaments and 19-11 record in national tourney play.
Boys Varsity
Curtis Roby, Trinity School
Coleman Crutchfield Dartmouth-bound senior captured the Mayor's Cup singles title. Roby is the USTA Eastern Section's fourth-ranked player, and is ranked No. 92 nationally in boys 18-and-under play. As Trinity's top singles player, Roby led his team to the Ivy League finals.
Coleman Crutchfield, Riverdale Country Day
The second seed in the Mayor's Cup, Crutchfield advanced to the finals, where he was bested by Roby. Crutchfield, who is ranked both nationally and in the USTA Eastern section, will play one more season of tennis at Riverdale Country Day next year.
Greg Streat, Beacon School
Junior compiled a 9-1 record as Beacon's third singles player. The Brooklyn product advanced to the Mayor's Cup semifinals, losing to second-seeded Crutchfield.
Danlahdi Robinson Jeffrey Kessler, Xaverian
The Mayor's Cup fourth seed, Kessler advanced to the semifinals before falling to eventual champ Roby. Kessler is ranked No. 22 in USTA Eastern boys 16-and-under play and No. 36 in 18-and-under play.
Asika Isoh, Gateway to Health Sciences
Talented sophomore was selected for the New York Junior Tennis League 2007 Tournament Team. The Queens product is widely considered a rising star on the New York City tennis circuit.
Danlahdi Robinson, Brooklyn Tech
Haig Schneiderman Junior played second singles and first doubles for Brooklyn Tech. Led Engineers to city finals and advanced to quarterfinals at Mayor's Cup.
Milo Hauk, Beacon School
Beacon's first singles player earned third seed at Mayor's Cup. Currently ranks No. 30 in the USTA Eastern division.
Haig Schneiderman, Horace Mann
Horace Mann's first singles dispatched Indiana-bound rival Jai Yoon in three sets, helping Lions to Mayor's Cup team title.
Andre Vorobyov, Brooklyn Tech
Engineers' first singles player completed junior year by helping Tech to PSAL semifinals. Strong Mayor's Cup performance could be sign of things to come.
Jai Yoon, Cardozo
Judges' first singles player finished senior season with 7-2 record and PSAL singles title. Also helped Judges to 2007 PSAL team title. Will play for Indiana University this fall.
Get in on the racket
This week, the New York Junior Tennis League is opening its annual summer tennis programs at some 60 sites throughout the five boroughs. The no-cost programs run through Aug. 24, are open to children ages 6-18 of all skill levels and equipment is provided. To find a program near you, call (718) 786-7110, ext. 8126, or visit www.nyjtl.org .
